instruction: Create a new layer called 'Walls' with red color
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
rs.AddLayer("Walls", (255,0,0))

instruction: List all layer names in the document
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
layers = rs.LayerNames()
for l in layers:
    print(l)

instruction: Turn off visibility for a layer named 'Construction'
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
rs.LayerVisible("Construction", False)

instruction: Delete all empty layers in the document
Move all selected objects to a layer named 'Final'
Create a layer hierarchy: 'Building' with sublayers 'Floors' and 'Roof'
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
rs.AddLayer("Building")
rs.AddLayer("Building::Floors")
rs.AddLayer("Building::Roof")

instruction: Set the color of a selected object to blue
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
obj = rs.GetObject("Select object")
if obj:
    rs.ObjectColor(obj, (0, 0, 255))

instruction: Assign a name to a selected object
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
obj = rs.GetObject("Select object to name")
if obj:
    rs.ObjectName(obj, "MyObject")

instruction: Set the material of an object to a glossy red
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
obj = rs.GetObject("Select object")
if obj:
    idx = rs.AddMaterialToObject(obj)
    rs.MaterialColor(idx, (255, 0, 0))
    rs.MaterialShine(idx, 200)

instruction: Group selected objects together
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
objs = rs.GetObjects("Select objects to group")
if objs:
    rs.AddObjectsToGroup(objs, rs.AddGroup())

instruction: Ungroup a selected group
Insert a block instance from an existing block definition
Define a new block from selected objects
Select all curves in the document
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
curves = rs.ObjectsByType(4)
if curves:
    rs.SelectObjects(curves)
    print("Selected", len(curves), "curves")

instruction: Select all objects on a specific layer
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
objs = rs.ObjectsByLayer("Default")
if objs:
    rs.SelectObjects(objs)
    print("Selected", len(objs), "objects")

instruction: Filter objects by color — select only red objects
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
all_objs = rs.AllObjects()
red_objs = [o for o in all_objs if rs.ObjectColor(o) == (255,0,0)]
if red_objs:
    rs.SelectObjects(red_objs)
    print("Selected", len(red_objs), "red objects")

instruction: Export selected objects to a new 3dm file
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
objs = rs.GetObjects("Select objects to export")
if objs:
    rs.SelectObjects(objs)
    rs.Command("_-Export \"/tmp/exported.3dm\" _Enter")

instruction: Import geometry from another 3dm file
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
rs.Command('_-Import "/path/to/file.3dm" _Enter')

instruction: Lock all objects on a layer to prevent editing
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
rs.LayerLocked("Construction", True)

instruction: Set an object's user text key-value pair
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
obj = rs.GetObject("Select object")
if obj:
    rs.SetUserText(obj, "Type", "Column")
    val = rs.GetUserText(obj, "Type")
    print("Stored:", val)

instruction: Create a layer with RhinoCommon and set its color
code:
import Rhino
import scriptcontext as sc
import System.Drawing

layer = Rhino.DocObjects.Layer()
layer.Name = "RhinoCommonLayer"
layer.Color = System.Drawing.Color.FromArgb(0, 128, 255)
sc.doc.Layers.Add(layer)
sc.doc.Views.Redraw()

instruction: Iterate all objects and print their type and layer
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
for obj in rs.AllObjects():
    obj_type = rs.ObjectType(obj)
    layer = rs.ObjectLayer(obj)
    print("Type:", obj_type, "Layer:", layer)

instruction: Purge all unused block definitions
Change the current layer to 'Default'
code:
import rhinoscriptsyntax as rs
rs.CurrentLayer("Default")
